ground_truth: The rumble is building and then erupts into a deafening roar as a wall of water crashes through the hollow, engulfing everything and everybody. The cabin itself is ripped away, and the Soggy Bottom Boys are knocked off their feet amid noise and confusion. Suddenly, the world becomes silent as Everett tumbles in the current in natural slow motion, suspended around scores of tins of Dapper Dan pomade. Other objects, including framed sepia-tinted family portraits, tree limbs, a fishing pole, an outhouse door, a frying pan, a noose, an old banjo, a wild-eyed frantically paddling bloodhound, and a tire with a rope tied around it, spin slowly by. The churning torrent opens into a lowland, becoming a newly created river, fast-moving but no longer violent. After a moment holding on the rippling waters, the surface is broken as a pine coffin up-bobs and floats downstream, soon joined by Everett, who gasps for air, shakes his head clear of water, and finishes freeing himself from the rope round his wrists. Pete and Delmar emerge nearby, also gasping for air, and the men hang onto the coffin that bears them downstream. Dazed, they look around at the inundated valley, where only occasional roof- or treetops poke out of the newly formed river. Everett waxes smug but trails off as he notices a cottonhouse submerged to its eaves with a cow on its roof staring at him, a stare he returns before shaking off the vision and clearing his throat. Downstream, Tommy surfaces, clinging to a half-submerged piece of furniture that begins to rotate in the current, causing him to climb in place like a hamster on a wheel to stay above water. Meanwhile, Everett and Penny walk arm in arm with the seven Wharvey gals behind, the girls singing 'Angel Band' as the grown-ups talk. Everett fumbles in his pocket and shakes his head, prompting Penny to quicken her pace in indignation, and he keeps up as they pull forward out of frame. The Wharvey gals follow in a ragged bunch, still singing, as the second-to-last and oldest girl holds a piece of string that leads our gaze to reveal a train track in the distance. The blind seer pumps his car along the distant track, singing harmony under the Wharvey gals' receding voices.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: The roar is growing and then detonates into a earsplitting bellow as a barricade of liquid smashes through the cavity, swallowing everything and everyone. The hut itself is torn away, and the Soggy Bottom Boys are toppled off their feet amid clamor and chaos. Abruptly, the universe becomes quiet as Everett plunges in the stream in inherent slow sequence, suspended around numerous tins of Dapper Dan pomade. Other items, including framed sepia-tinted family illustrations, tree branches, a fishing rod, an outhouse door, a skillet, a noose, an aged banjo, a wild-eyed frantically paddling bloodhound, and a tire with a cord tied around it, revolve gradually by. The swirling flood opens into a lowland, becoming a freshly formed river, rapid-moving but no longer fierce. After a moment holding on the rippling waters, the surface is broken as a pine casket bob-ups and floats downstream, soon accompanied by Everett, who gasps for air, shakes his head clear of liquid, and finishes freeing himself from the rope round his wrists. Pete and Delmar surface nearby, also gasping for air, and the men cling onto the casket that carries them downstream. Stunned, they look around at the deluged valley, where only occasional roof- or treetops protrude out of the newly created river. Everett waxes complacent but trails off as he perceives a cottonhouse submerged to its eaves with a cow on its rooftop staring at him, a gaze he returns before shaking off the sight and clearing his throat. Downstream, Tommy emerges, clinging to a half-submerged piece of furniture that starts to rotate in the current, causing him to climb in place like a hamster on a wheel to remain above the liquid. Meanwhile, Everett and Penny walk arm in arm with the seven Wharvey gals behind, the girls singing 'Angel Band' as the grown-ups converse. Everett fumbles in his pocket and shakes his head, prompting Penny to hasten her stride in annoyance, and he keeps up as they pull forward out of frame. The Wharvey gals follow in a ragged bunch, still singing, as the second-to-last and oldest girl holds a piece of twine that leads our gaze to uncover a railway track in the distance. The blind prophet pumps his car along the distant track, singing harmony under the Wharvey gals' receding voices.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: The rumble is being built and then is erupted into a deafening roar as a wall of water is crashed through the hollow, engulfing everything and everybody. The cabin itself rips away, and noise and confusion knock off the Soggy Bottom Boys from their feet. Suddenly, the world becomes silent as Everett is tumbled in the current in natural slow motion, surrounded by scores of tins of Dapper Dan pomade. Other objects, which include framed sepia-tinted family portraits, tree limbs, a fishing pole, an outhouse door, a frying pan, a noose, an old banjo, a wild-eyed frantically paddling bloodhound, and a tire with a rope tied around it, are spun slowly by. The churning torrent is opened into a lowland, creating a newly formed river, which moves fast but is no longer violent. After a moment of holding on the rippling waters, the surface breaks as a pine coffin is up-bobbed and floats downstream, soon joining Everett, who gasps for air, shakes his head clear of water, and finishes freeing himself from the rope tied around his wrists. Pete and Delmar are emerging nearby, also gasping for air, and the men are hanging onto the coffin that carries them downstream. Dazed, they look around at the inundated valley, where the newly formed river occasionally pokes roof- or treetops. Smugness is waxed by Everett but trails off as he notices a cottonhouse submerged to its eaves with a cow on its roof staring at him, a stare he returns before shaking off the vision and clearing his throat. Downstream, Tommy surfaces, and clings to a half-submerged piece of furniture that rotates in the current, causing him to climb in place like a hamster on a wheel to stay above water. Meanwhile, Everett walks arm in arm with Penny and the seven Wharvey gals behind, the girls singing 'Angel Band' as the grown-ups talk. A fumble is made by Everett in his pocket and his head is shaken, prompting Penny to quicken her pace in indignation, and he keeps up as they pull forward out of frame. The Wharvey gals follow in a ragged bunch, still singing, as the second-to-last and oldest girl holds a piece of string that leads our gaze to reveal a train track in the distance. The blind seer is pumping his car along the distant track, singing harmony under the Wharvey gals' receding voices.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: The rumble builds into a deafening roar as a wall of water crashes through the hollow, engulfing everything. The cabin is swept away, and the Soggy Bottom Boys are knocked off their feet in confusion. Suddenly, silence falls as Everett tumbles in the current, surrounded by tins of Dapper Dan pomade. Various objects, including portraits, tree limbs, and a paddling bloodhound, spin by. The torrent flows into a lowland, forming a fast-moving but calmer river. A pine coffin surfaces and floats downstream, joined by Everett, who gasps for air and frees himself from a rope. Pete and Delmar emerge, holding onto the coffin in the inundated valley. Everett notices a cottonhouse submerged with a cow on its roof, staring at him. Downstream, Tommy clings to rotating furniture, climbing to stay afloat. Meanwhile, Everett walks with Penny, the Wharvey gals behind singing 'Angel Band.' Everett fumbles in his pocket, Penny quickens her pace, and they move out of frame with the girls following, revealing a train track. The blind seer sings harmony as he pumps his car along the track.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: The rumble builds to a deafening roar as water crashes through the hollow, engulfing everything. The cabin is swept away, and the Soggy Bottom Boys are knocked down amid chaos. Suddenly silent, Everett tumbles in slow motion among tins of Dapper Dan pomade and other objects, like portraits, tree limbs, and a bloodhound. The torrent opens into a river. A pine coffin surfaces, joined by Everett, gasping for air and freeing himself from a rope. Pete and Delmar appear, clinging to the coffin. Dazed, they see the flooded valley with rooftops emerging and a cow on a cottonhouse. Downstream, Tommy clings to furniture, rotating and climbing like a hamster. Meanwhile, Everett and Penny walk, followed by the Wharvey gals singing 'Angel Band.' Everettâ€™s head shake prompts Penny to quicken her pace. The gals follow, revealing a train track in the distance with the blind seer pumping along, harmonizing with their voices.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: The overwhelming rumble steadily grows in intensity until it erupts into an ear-splitting roar. A massive wall of water comes crashing powerfully through the hollow, engulfing and consuming everything and everyone it encounters in its path. The cabin itself is torn away with incredible force, while the bewildered Soggy Bottom Boys find themselves knocked off their feet, caught amidst a cacophony of noise and sheer confusion. In a sudden shift, the world around Everett becomes eerily silent as he tumbles within the current, captured in an almost dreamlike slow motion. He is surrounded by countless tins of Dapper Dan pomade, floating alongside him. Other assorted objects drift by: framed family portraits, tinged with sepia, tree limbs, a fishing pole, the door of an outhouse, a simple frying pan, a noose, an old and well-worn banjo, a wild-eyed bloodhound frantically paddling, and a tire with a rope tied securely around it, all spinning slowly in the chaotic water. As the churning torrent unfurls into a broad lowland area, it gradually transforms into a newly created river. This river, though fast-moving, is no longer violently turbulent. After a momentary focus on the rippling waters, the surface is abruptly broken as a pine coffin unexpectedly bobs up and begins to float downstream. It is not long before Everett joins it, emerging with a desperate gasp for air. He shakes his head vigorously to clear the water from his senses and works to finish freeing himself from the rope securely tied around his wrists. Nearby, Pete and Delmar also surface, gasping desperately for air. They cling tightly to the coffin, allowing it to bear them downstream. Dazed and disoriented, they glance around, taking in the inundated valley where only occasional rooftops or treetops can still be seen poking out from beneath the newly formed river. Everett, feeling smug, begins to wax poetic but trails off as he notices a cottonhouse submerged up to its eaves. A cow stands on its roof, staring directly at him. He returns the stare, momentarily captivated, before shaking off the peculiar vision and clearing his throat. Further downstream, Tommy surfaces clinging to a half-submerged piece of furniture. As the furniture rotates in the current, Tommy is forced to climb in place, resembling a hamster furiously running on a wheel to stay above the water's surface. Meanwhile, Everett and Penny stroll arm in arm with the seven Wharvey girls trailing behind. The girls sing 'Angel Band' softly while the adults engage in conversation. Searching his pocket, Everett frowns and shakes his head, causing Penny to quicken her pace indignantly. He matches her speed to keep up as they move forward and out of the frame. The Wharvey gals follow along in a disordered group, their singing persisting, as the second-to-last and oldest girl in line holds onto a piece of string. This string leads our gaze to a distant set of train tracks. The blind seer is seen pumping his handcar along the faraway track, singing in harmony with the Wharvey girls' gradually fading voices.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: The overwhelming rumble of sound steadily and relentlessly grows in intensity, building up until it erupts into a deafening, ear-splitting roar that seems to shake the very ground. A massive, formidable wall of water comes crashing powerfully and violently through the hollow, engulfing and consuming everything and everyone it encounters along its unstoppable path. The cabin itself is mercilessly torn away with incredible force, while the bewildered Soggy Bottom Boys find themselves knocked off their feet, thrust into a state of disarray amidst a cacophony of loud noise and utter confusion. In a sudden, almost startling shift, the world around Everett becomes eerily and unnaturally silent as he tumbles helplessly within the swirling current, captured in an almost dreamlike, surreal slow motion. He finds himself surrounded by countless tins of Dapper Dan pomade, which float alongside him. Other assorted objects drift byâ€”the detritus of lives uprooted: framed family portraits, tinged with sepia and nostalgia, tree limbs torn from their places, a fishing pole with its line trailing, the door of an outhouse, a simple, unassuming frying pan, a noose that speaks of dark stories untold, an old and well-worn banjo, a wild-eyed bloodhound frantically paddling for its life, and a tire with a rope tied securely around it, all spinning slowly in the chaotic, swirling water. As the churning torrent unfurls into a broad, expansive lowland area, it gradually transforms into a newly created river. This river, though swift and fast-moving, is no longer violently turbulent and aggressive. After a brief moment of focus on the rippling waters, the surface is abruptly and unexpectedly broken as a pine coffin bobs up and begins to float downstream. It is not long before Everett joins it in this surreal tableau, emerging with a desperate, gasping breath for air. He shakes his head vigorously in an attempt to clear the water from his senses and works to finish freeing himself from the rope that is securely tied around his wrists. Nearby, Pete and Delmar also make their way to the surface, gasping desperately for air. They cling tightly to the coffin, allowing it to bear them gently downstream. Dazed and disoriented, they glance around, taking in the inundated valley where only occasional rooftops or treetops can still be seen poking out from beneath the newly formed river. Everett, feeling somewhat smug, begins to wax poetic but trails off as he notices a cottonhouse submerged up to its eaves. A cow stands inelegantly on its roof, staring directly and intently at him. He returns the stare, momentarily captivated by the peculiar vision, before shaking off the strangeness and clearing his throat. Further downstream, Tommy surfaces clinging desperately to a half-submerged piece of furniture. As the piece of furniture rotates precariously in the current, Tommy is forced to climb in place, resembling a frantic hamster furiously running on a wheel to stay above the water's threatening surface. Meanwhile, Everett and Penny stroll arm in arm with the seven Wharvey girls trailing quietly behind. The girls sing 'Angel Band' softly and sweetly while the adults engage in conversation. Searching his pocket, Everett frowns and shakes his head, causing Penny to quicken her pace with a sense of indignation. He matches her speed hastily to keep up as they move forward and out of the frame. The Wharvey gals follow along in a charmingly disordered group, their harmonious singing persisting, as the second-to-last and oldest girl in line holds onto a thin piece of string. This string leads our gaze to a distant set of train tracks. The blind seer is seen pumping his handcar rhythmically along the faraway track, singing in harmonious union with the Wharvey girls' gradually fading voices.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: The rumble begins as a faint tremor but quickly intensifies, building with increasing force until it erupts into an overwhelming, deafening roar. This tremendous noise heralds the arrival of a colossal wall of water that crashes forcefully through the hollow, consuming everything and everyone in its path with relentless power. The cabin itself is violently torn away, and the Soggy Bottom Boys are caught in the torrent, knocked off their feet amid a chaotic symphony of noise and confusion, their footing lost to the sheer force of the deluge. In a sudden, surreal shift, the world around Everett becomes eerily silent. He tumbles helplessly within the current, moving as if in natural slow motion. Suspended in the water, he is surrounded by a swirling collection of tins of Dapper Dan pomade, drifting aimlessly. Alongside him, other objects float past with a gentle, dreamlike quality, including framed sepia-tinted family portraits, tree limbs, a fishing pole, an outhouse door, a frying pan, a noose, an old banjo, a wildly paddling bloodhound with frantic eyes, and a tire tied with a rope, all spinning slowly by in the water's embrace. As the churning torrent expands, it opens up into a lowland area, transforming into a newly created river that flows quickly but with a less violent current. After a brief moment where the camera lingers on the rippling waters, the surface is suddenly disrupted as a pine coffin emerges, bobbing upward and beginning to float downstream. This coffin is shortly joined by Everett, who bursts to the surface, gasping desperately for air as he shakes his head to fling off the water clinging to his face. He works quickly to free himself from the ropes binding his wrists, finally managing to release them. Nearby, Pete and Delmar also break the surface, both gasping for air, and together the men clutch onto the floating coffin that now carries them gently downstream. In a state of dazed bewilderment, they survey the scene around them, taking in the sight of the inundated valley, where only the occasional roof or treetop rises above the newly formed river's expanse. Everett, with a hint of smugness in his expression, begins to boast before trailing off distractedly as he notices a cottonhouse submerged up to its eaves, with a solitary cow perched on its roof. The cow gazes intently at Everett, locking eyes with him for a moment before he shakes off the peculiar vision and clears his throat, refocusing his attention. Further downstream, Tommy surfaces as well, clinging tightly to a half-submerged piece of furniture caught in the current. As it begins to rotate, Tommy is forced to scramble in place, akin to a hamster on a wheel, to maintain his balance and stay above the water. Meanwhile, a scene unfolds where Everett and Penny walk closely together, arm in arm, with the seven Wharvey gals following behind them in a cluster. As the girls sing 'Angel Band' softly, the grown-ups engage in conversation. Everett searches his pocket, fumbling with purpose, only to shake his head in slight frustration. This gesture causes Penny to quicken her pace, her expression showing clear indignation. Everett adjusts his step to keep up with her urgency as they move forward, gradually disappearing from view. In their wake, the Wharvey gals continue to follow, maintaining their ragged formation while singing, with the second-to-last and oldest girl holding onto a piece of string. Their movement draws the gaze forward, revealing a train track off in the distance. On this track, the blind seer is seen pumping his handcar, moving along the rails while singing in harmony with the receding voices of the Wharvey gals, whose song fades gently into the distance.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: The rumble builds and erupts into a deafening roar as a wall of water crashes through the hollow, engulfing everything and everybody. The cabin is torn away, and the Soggy Bottom Boys are swept off their feet amid the chaos. Suddenly, Everett is suspended in the current, surrounded by spinning objects like tins of Dapper Dan pomade, family portraits, tree limbs, and a banjo. The torrent opens into a lowland, forming a fast-moving river. As the water ripples, a pine coffin surfaces, with Everett gasping for air, shaking off water, and freeing himself from the rope around his wrists. Pete and Delmar appear nearby, also gasping, and they cling to the coffin as they drift downstream. Dazed, they observe the inundated valley with roofs and treetops peeking out of the newly formed river. Everett feels smug but pauses as he notices a cottonhouse submerged to its eaves with a cow on its roof, returning its stare before clearing his throat. Downstream, Tommy surfaces on a rotating piece of furniture, struggling to stay above water. Meanwhile, Everett and Penny walk arm in arm with the seven Wharvey gals singing 'Angel Band' as they talk. Everett searches his pocket and shakes his head, causing Penny to quicken her pace in indignation, and he matches her speed as they move out of frame. The Wharvey gals follow in a ragged bunch, still singing, with the second-to-last girl holding a string that draws the viewerâ€™s gaze to a distant train track. The blind seer pumps his car along the track, singing in harmony under the Wharvey gals' receding voices.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: The rumble is building and then erupts into a deafening roar as a wall of water, likely due to a sudden dam break or an intense storm, crashes through the hollow, engulfing everything and everybody in its path. The cabin itself, one that had likely stood in the valley for decades, is ripped away, and the Soggy Bottom Boys, a musical group named after their lively bluegrass performances, are knocked off their feet amid the overwhelming noise and confusion. Suddenly, the world becomes silent as Everett tumbles in the current in natural slow motion, suspended around scores of tins of Dapper Dan pomade, a popular hair product from the early 20th century known for its strong hold and distinctive scent. Other objects, including framed sepia-tinted family portraits from an era that cherished the preservation of family legacy, tree limbs from ancient oaks that once lined the valley, a fishing pole reminiscent of lazy afternoons spent by the river, an outhouse door that served the cabin's modest restroom needs, a frying pan used for countless hearty meals, a noose that ominously hints at darker times, an old banjo resonating with echoes of Southern folk music, a wild-eyed frantically paddling bloodhound, a loyal companion in many a hunting expedition, and a tire with a rope tied around it used as a makeshift swing, spin slowly by. The churning torrent opens into a lowland, becoming a newly created river, fast-moving but no longer violent. After a moment holding on the rippling waters, the surface is broken as a pine coffin, likely dislodged from a nearby cemetery, up-bobs and floats downstream, soon joined by Everett, who gasps for air, shakes his head clear of water, and finishes freeing himself from the rope round his wrists. Pete and Delmar emerge nearby, also gasping for air, and the men hang onto the coffin that bears them downstream, evoking imagery from classic Southern folklore about survival and resilience. Dazed, they look around at the inundated valley, where only occasional roof- or treetops poke out of the newly formed river, illustrating the devastating impact of the flood. Everett waxes smug but trails off as he notices a cottonhouse submerged to its eaves with a cow on its roof staring at him, a surreal sight reminiscent of biblical flood stories, a stare he returns before shaking off the vision and clearing his throat. Downstream, Tommy surfaces, clinging to a half-submerged piece of furniture that begins to rotate in the current, causing him to climb in place like a hamster on a wheel to stay above water, a comical yet desperate struggle for survival. Meanwhile, Everett and Penny walk arm in arm with the seven Wharvey gals behind, the girls singing 'Angel Band,' a traditional hymn often associated with comfort in times of hardship, as the grown-ups talk. Everett fumbles in his pocket and shakes his head, recalling his character's notorious vanity and trouble with finances, prompting Penny to quicken her pace in indignation, and he keeps up as they pull forward out of frame. The Wharvey gals follow in a ragged bunch, still singing, as the second-to-last and oldest girl holds a piece of string that leads our gaze to reveal a train track in the distance, symbolizing a path to a hopeful future. The blind seer, a recurring prophetic figure in tales of adventure and fate, pumps his car along the distant track, singing harmony under the Wharvey gals' receding voices, offering a final note of mystical guidance.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The thundercloud gathers and then shatters into a deafening crash as a herd of elephants thunders through the meadow, consuming anything and everyone. The outhouse itself is torn apart, and the Merry Meadow Maids are tossed off their bicycles amid chaos and disorder. Abruptly, the universe becomes calm as Hector drifts in the breeze in mystical slow motion, surrounded by piles of jars of Golden Goose marmalade. Various items, such as monochrome-filtered childhood drawings, bush branches, a hiking stick, a barn door, a cooking pot, a lasso, an ancient guitar, a wide-eyed, frantically flapping parrot, and a balloon with a string tied around it, rotate gently by. The rumbling wind opens into a plateau, transforming into a freshly formed path, quick-moving but no longer chaotic. After a pause on the shimmering light, the air is broken as a birch barrel bobs up and glides downstream, soon joined by Hector, who inhales deeply, shakes his hair free of dust, and completes freeing himself from the string around his ankles. Frank and Donny appear nearby, also inhaling deeply, and the friends cling to the barrel that carries them downstream. Bewildered, they glance around at the drenched plain, where only scattered door- or treetops protrude from the newly shaped path. Hector beams proudly but falters as he notices a birdhouse flooded to its eaves with a goat on its peak gazing at him, an exchange he mirrors before dismissing the sight and clearing his voice. Downstream, Timmy emerges, clutching a half-submerged piece of luggage that starts spinning in the breeze, making him leap in place like a rabbit on a wheel to remain above ground. Meanwhile, Hector and Paula stroll hand in hand with the nine Myrtle boys behind, the lads humming 'Heavenly Choir' as the adults chat. Hector digs in his backpack and shakes his shoulders, prompting Paula to speed up in irritation, and he matches pace as they move forward out of view. The Myrtle boys follow in a jumbled group, still humming, as the middle and tallest boy grasps a length of yarn that guides our vision to reveal a bridge in the distance. The wise oracle propels his cart along the distant road, harmonizing under the Myrtle boys' fading hums.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby cafÃ©, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: A deafening roar signals a wall of water crashing through, engulfing everything, including the Soggy Bottom Boys, who are swept off their feet. In the chaos, Everett sees various objects and companions floating by, and soon emerges from the torrent, freeing himself from his bindings. He finds Pete and Delmar, who cling to a coffin to stay afloat in the newly formed river. Everett's smugness fades when he spots a surreal scene of a cow atop a submerged cottonhouse. Downstream, Tommy struggles to stay above water on a piece of furniture. Meanwhile, Everett walks with Penny, followed by the singing Wharvey gals. As they converse, Penny's pace quickens with indignation as Everett searches his pocket. The Wharvey gals, still singing, lead the scene to a distant train track where a blind seer pumps his car, harmonizing with their voices.

test_cases.name: Reverse Segments Order
test_cases.description: The blind seer pumps his car along the distant track singing harmony under the Wharvey gals' receding voices The Wharvey gals follow in a ragged bunch still singing as the secondtolast and oldest girl holds a piece of string that leads our gaze to reveal a train track in the distance Everett fumbles in his pocket and shakes his head prompting Penny to quicken her pace in indignation and he keeps up as they pull forward out of frame Meanwhile Everett and Penny walk arm in arm with the seven Wharvey gals behind the girls singing 'Angel Band' as the grownups talk Downstream Tommy surfaces clinging to a halfsubmerged piece of furniture that begins to rotate in the current causing him to climb in place like a hamster on a wheel to stay above water he returns before shaking off the vision and clearing his throat Everett waxes smug but trails off as he notices a cottonhouse submerged to its eaves with a cow on its roof staring at him a stare Dazed they look around at the inundated valley where only occasional roof or treetops poke out of the newly formed river Pete and Delmar emerge nearby also gasping for air and the men hang onto the coffin that bears them downstream After a moment holding on the rippling waters the surface is broken as a pine coffin upbobs and floats downstream soon joined by Everett who gasps for air shakes his head clear of everybody
